meaning_mnemonic: This L-shaped radical is the <radical>lion</radical> radical, because "L" is for "Lion." It also looks like a lion's mouth being opened really, really wide. Imagine a lion opening its mouth to yawn. It looks like this radical!

This is a <radical>knife</radical>. See the sharp edge on the left and the tapered tip on top? And there's a little handle at the bottom for the... well, the handle. Be careful you don't cut yourself on this knife!
There's a <radical>ladle</radical> scooping up two drops of liquid. See the handle and the scoop part of the ladle? Imagine ladling some water into your mouth. Mmm.

First of all, there's a cross making up the middle, which automatically makes this a religion-based radical. That cross is the frame of someone's body and the things coming off of it are wings. This is an <radical>angel</radical>.
This radical looks like the fire from the burner of a stove. That's because this is the <radical>boil</radical> radical. You need to boil a bunch of water over some flames.

This radical looks like a <radical>yakuza</radical>. See him facing left, with that threatening jawline and big pompadour hairstyle? Maybe imagine a couple scars on his face too. You know, real yakuza-like.

You could also remember this because it’s the evening radical under the ground radical, and people who do stuff underground in the evening (and night) are definitely yakuza.
There's a head with a little bit of hair on the top. There's also one big eye in the middle. Only one creature has a head like this, and that creature is the <radical>cyclops</radical>.

This is like one of those <radical>jet</radical>s that have the little nose-wings going on too. Imagine you're looking at the jet from the top down, this is what it would look like. It's also why this is the jet radical.

This is a tree with a drooping slide shape on top. What causes the top of plants to sag? The <radical>grain</radical>s. Imagine seeing how the heads of wheat or rice droop when they're ready for harvest. It will look like this radical. Look at all that ripe grain!

This might remind you of 米, which has three stalks sprouting upward. You can tell the difference because the top of this one is slanted from the weight of the ripe grain.
This is a very fluffy <radical>sheep</radical>. See the two horns poking up and all its wool poking out to the side? It's so fluffy that you can hardly see its tiny little legs. What a cute sheep!

You see a little drop of something on your plate. Oh no… it's <radical>BLOOD</radical>!!! Yep, you're bleeding. Now you have to wash that plate again — just as soon as the bleeding stops. Don't worry, your platelets should stop the bleeding soon. Haha, get it? PLATE-lets? Like blood platelets? Japanese blood jokes.
When a stick figure has hair that drags on the ground and gets kicked all the time, you know that hair's gotta be <radical>long</radical>. Why is it so looooong?!
You put on your hat and go outside to kick something white. It's a big white goose and you killed it with your kick. That's because you're going to cook and <radical>eat</radical> it. Yum!

This radical is just like the katakana character "ma" (マ). So let's keep things simple and make the radical <radical>mama</radical>. It even looks like a mama leaning over and gently tapping her baby to help them fall asleep.

Someone has a toe in their mouth. They are a fortune teller telling your <radical>fortune</radical>. But for her to do it, she has to take one of your toes and taste it. This better be a good fortune for you to let someone put your foot in their mouth.

This is the radical for <radical>neck</radical>. Look, you can see all the vertebrae stacked up, and the little ligaments that connect it to the base of the skull! That's why this is the radical for neck.

This is the <radical>tongue</radical> radical. See that sturdy slide holding a thousand people above a mouth? An open mouth can't support that much weight, but a strong tongue can — it's the muscle of the mouth, after all.

Alternatively, you can think of this as something sticking out of a mouth with thousands of tiny taste buds on it. It's your tongue!

There's a lid on a lion. And you're stuck under the lid with the lion, which means you will surely meet your <radical>death</radical>. Or if you don't want to die, think of the poor lion. If you leave a lion under a lid for too long, death will come for it too. Either way, somebody's gonna die today.
Behind that tree the sun is rising in the <radical>east</radical>. The sun always rises in the east, so if you head that way, past the tree, you'll be going east too.

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>city</radical>.

In case you don't remember the kanji's meaning mnemonic, here's a refresher:

You see a manhole <radical>lid</radical> and a <radical>towel</radical>, both with the name of a <kanji>city</kanji> on them. Decorative manhole lids and souvenir towels — two things cities love to slap their names on, especially in Japan.

Under this roof is a pig with her little ones. Your pig, because it's your <radical>house</radical>! You keep your piggies inside where it's nice and warm. They're all members of your family, so they deserve to live in your house too.
